Synapse provides two systems for extending functionality: middlewares and plugins. They serve different roles and have different scopes of application.

Middlewares in Synapse work on the principle of "handler chain" and allow intercepting any storage operations. Each middleware can modify actions before and after their processing by the base storage.
Middlewares are executed in the order they are declared in the array:
Action goes through all middlewares from top to bottom
Then the base storage operation is executed
Result goes through middlewares from bottom to top

data.text: BroadcastMiddleware should be first for tab synchronization
I'll add more detailed examples later
Plugins in Synapse represent a system of storage event handlers with a defined lifecycle. Unlike middlewares, they don't form a chain but work as independent "observers" of storage operations.
Plugins have the following lifecycle methods:
Initialization: initialize() - called when adding plugin to storage
Destruction: destroy() - called when removing plugin or destroying storage
When to use middlewares vs plugins?
Intercepting all storage operations in one place
Changing behavior of base storage operations
Implementing business logic related to data storage
